page.title: 2006 murder of TRO workers in Sri Lanka

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{coord|9.666|80|display=title}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Murder of TRO workers | image = | caption = | location = [[Welikanda]], [[Sri Lanka]] | coordinates = | target = [[Sri Lankan Tamil]] civilians | date = 2006 | time = | timezone = +6 GMT | type = Unknown | fatalities = 7 | injuries = | perps = | susperps = [[TMVP]] paramilitary group<ref>>{{cite news | title= Tragic fate of TRO employees abducted by TMVP in January 2006| date=| publisher=| url =http://dbsjeyaraj.com/dbsj/archives/1187| work =[[D. B. S. Jeyaraj]]| accessdate = 2017-08-05}}</ref> | weapons = Unknown }} '''2006 murder of TRO workers''' refers to the incident of abduction of seven [[Tamils Rehabilitation Organisation]] (TRO) employees who were tortured and executed by the [[TMVP]] paramilitary group. One employee Premini Thanuskodi was gang raped and murdered.<ref>[https://www.colombotelegraph.com/index.php/remembering-the-abduction-of-tro-staff-on-29-30-january-2006/ Remembering The Abduction Of TRO Staff On 29 & 30 January, 2006]</ref><ref>[http://tamilnation.co/indictment/continuingwar/060130tro.htm#Memorial_service Sri Lanka Paramilitaries abduct Tamil staff members of Tamils Rehabilitation Organization (TRO) in Welikande/Batticaloa, 30 January 2006]</ref>
==Abduction== Seven TRO workers were abducted in two separate incident on January 2006 in [[Jaffna]]. The first incident happened when five workers were traveling from [[Batticalo]] to [[Kilinochchi]]. They were subjected to checks at the [[Sri Lanka Army]] checkpoint at Welikanda. At this point they noticed a white van behind them. After traveling a short distance from the checkpoint the workers were attacked by armed men in the white van. The assaulter then tied the workers and took them to a camp in the jungle. Three of the five abducted were released later. The next day another 15 workers were abducted 100 meters in front of the Walikanda checkpoint. 10 of the 15 abducted were released and were told to prepare the funeral rights for their colleges.<ref name='AI'>{{cite news | title=SRI LANKA | date=2007-06-10 | publisher=AI | url=http://www.amnesty.be/doc/article7274.html | work=Amnesty international | accessdate=2007-07-03 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120718051221/http://www.amnesty.be/doc/article7274.html | archive-date=2012-07-18 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref>
==Reaction== The President of Sri Lanka has asked the security forces to speed up the investigation concerning the abduction of the TRO workers. He further asked to search the Walikanda area for the abducted. The government also denied any links to this abduction.
[[Tamils Rehabilitation Organisation]] has alleged that their staff were abducted by the [[TamilEela Makkal Viduthalai Pulikal|Karuna Group]], a paramilitary organization which is believed to be working with the Sri Lankan Armed Forces. It further added that they have not received any reports or response from any investigating authorities.<ref name='TRO'>{{cite news | title= Abducted TRO Aid Workers Believed Dead| date=2007-07-05 | publisher=TRO | url =http://www.troonline.org/123aboutus.htm| work =| accessdate = 2007-07-05 }}</ref>
The [[Amnesty International]] has asked for the immediate release of these workers <ref name="AI"/>
The former US [[Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs]], Christina Rocca, made an appeal for their release.<ref name="TRO"/>
The [[LTTE]] expressed concern over the abduction of the TRO workers.<ref name='BBC'>{{cite news | title= Swift probe ordered on TRO abductions| date=2007-07-03 | publisher=BBC | url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/sinhala/news/story/2006/02/060205_ltte_president.shtml| work =BBC Sinhala| accessdate = 2007-07-03 }}</ref>
==Conflicting reports== UTHR reported that the [[LTTE]] had staged the abduction of the TRO workers but later said that they were not correct on this statement.<ref name='UTHR'>{{cite news | title=The Missing TRO workers| date=2007-07-03 | publisher=UTHR | url =http://www.uthr.org/bulletins/bul42.htm#_Toc153735236| work =| accessdate = 2007-07-03 }}</ref> However, TRO alleged that a government backed paramilitary was responsible for this abduction <ref name='BBC'/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Sri Lankan Civil War}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:TRO}} [[Category:Mass murder in 2006]] [[Category:Political repression]] [[Category:Civilian massacres in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Human rights abuses in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:2006 crimes in Sri Lanka]]

{{Orphan|date=December 2017}} [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)]], is a neurodegenerative disease that typically affects adults around 54-67<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chiò|first=A.|last2=Logroscino|first2=G.|last3=Traynor|first3=B.J.|last4=Collins|first4=J.|last5=Simeone|first5=J.C.|last6=Goldstein|first6=L.A.|last7=White|first7=L.A.|date=2013|title=Global Epidemiology of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis: A Systematic Review of the Published Literature|url=https://www.karger.com/Article/FullText/351153|journal=Neuroepidemiology|language=english|volume=41|issue=2|pages=118–130|doi=10.1159/000351153|issn=0251-5350|pmc=4049265}}</ref> years of age, although anyone can be diagnosed with the disease. People diagnosed with ALS live on average 2–4 years after diagnosis due to the quick progression of the disease.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hobson|first=Esther V.|last2=McDermott|first2=Christopher J.|title=Supportive and symptomatic management of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nrneurol.2016.111|journal=Nature Reviews Neurology|volume=12|issue=9|pages=526–538|doi=10.1038/nrneurol.2016.111}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.als.ca/about-als/|title=About ALS - ALS Society of Canada|work=ALS Society of Canada|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-US}}</ref> The progression and severity of ALS is rated by doctors on the ALS Functional Rating Scale, which has been revised and is referred to as ALSFRS-R.
== Criteria == ALSFRS-R includes 12 questions that can have a score of 0 to 4. A score of 0 on a question would indicate no function while a score of 4 would indicate full function.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=Sarah|last2=Al Khleifat|first2=Ahmad|last3=Al-Chalabi|first3=Ammar|date=2017-03-28|title=What causes amyotrophic lateral sclerosis?|journal=F1000Research|volume=6|doi=10.12688/f1000research.10476.1|issn=2046-1402|pmc=5373425|pmid=28408982}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Cedarbaum|first=Jesse M.|last2=Stambler|first2=Nancy|last3=Malta|first3=Errol|last4=Fuller|first4=Cynthia|last5=Hilt|first5=Dana|last6=Thurmond|first6=Barbara|last7=Nakanishi|first7=Arline|title=The ALSFRS-R: a revised ALS functional rating scale that incorporates assessments of respiratory function|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0022510X99002105|journal=Journal of the Neurological Sciences|volume=169|issue=1-2|pages=13–21|doi=10.1016/s0022-510x(99)00210-5}}</ref> This scale has been useful for doctors in diagnosing patients, measuring disease progression and also for researchers when selecting patients for a study and measuring the potential effects of a [[clinical trial]].<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mora|first=Jesús S|date=2017-10-01|title=Edaravone for treatment of early-stage ALS|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1474442217302892|journal=The Lancet Neurology|volume=16|issue=10|pages=772|doi=10.1016/S1474-4422(17)30289-2}}</ref>
The ALSFRS-R scale has some limitations though since it is not useful to compare scores of people who present with different onset. In [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|ALS]] the main type of onset is bulbar, followed by limb-onset; which describes the region of motor neurons first affected.<ref name=":0" /> Individuals may also present with respiratory onset,<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Rooney|first=James|last2=Burke|first2=Tom|last3=Vajda|first3=Alice|last4=Heverin|first4=Mark|last5=Hardiman|first5=Orla|date=2017-05-01|title=What does the ALSFRS-R really measure? A longitudinal and survival analysis of functional dimension subscores in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|url=http://jnnp.bmj.com/content/88/5/381|journal=J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry|language=en|volume=88|issue=5|pages=381–385|doi=10.1136/jnnp-2016-314661|issn=0022-3050|pmid=27888187}}</ref> but this occurs very rarely. Since there are three different types of ALS, ALSFRS-R scores are often grouped in categories depending on type of onset.<ref name=":3"/>
Since there are three main pathways of progression, the questions are also divided in relation to the types of onset. Questions 1 to 3 are related to bulbar onset, questions 4 to 9 are related to limb onset and questions 10-12 are related to respiratory onset.<ref name=":3" />
== Progression == ALSFRS-R scores calculated at diagnosis can be compared to scores throughout time to determine the speed of progression. The rate of change, called the ALSFRS-R slope can be used as a prognostic indicator.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kimura|first=F.|last2=Fujimura|first2=C.|last3=Ishida|first3=S.|last4=Nakajima|first4=H.|last5=Furutama|first5=D.|last6=Uehara|first6=H.|last7=Shinoda|first7=K.|last8=Sugino|first8=M.|last9=Hanafusa|first9=T.|date=2006-01-24|title=Progression rate of ALSFRS-R at time of diagnosis predicts survival time in ALS|url=http://www.neurology.org/content/66/2/265|journal=Neurology|language=en|volume=66|issue=2|pages=265–267|doi=10.1212/01.wnl.0000194316.91908.8a|issn=0028-3878|pmid=16434671}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Elamin|first=Marwa|last2=Bede|first2=Peter|last3=Montuschi|first3=Anna|last4=Pender|first4=Niall|last5=Chio|first5=Adriano|last6=Hardiman|first6=Orla|date=2015-06-01|title=Predicting prognosis in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: a simple algorithm|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00415-015-7731-6|journal=Journal of Neurology|language=en|volume=262|issue=6|pages=1447–1454|doi=10.1007/s00415-015-7731-6|issn=0340-5354|pmc=4469087}}</ref>
Although the ALSFRS-R score is a recognized prognostic indicator,<ref name=":2" /> it is more useful to compare various indicators including [[vital capacity]] (FVC%) and the Sickness Impact Profile (SIP)<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bergner|first=M.|last2=Bobbitt|first2=R. A.|last3=Carter|first3=W. B.|last4=Gilson|first4=B. S.|date=August 1981|title=The Sickness Impact Profile: development and final revision of a health status measure|journal=Medical Care|volume=19|issue=8|pages=787–805|issn=0025-7079|pmid=7278416}}</ref> to increase the accuracy of a given prognosis.
Relating the ALSFRS-R score to staging criteria is also useful in determining prognosis. King's system relies on the clinical spread of disease as a measure of progression<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Roche|first=Jose C.|last2=Rojas-Garcia|first2=Ricardo|last3=Scott|first3=Kirsten M.|last4=Scotton|first4=William|last5=Ellis|first5=Catherine E.|last6=Burman|first6=Rachel|last7=Wijesekera|first7=Lokesh|last8=Turner|first8=Martin R.|last9=Leigh|first9=P. Nigel|date=March 2012|title=A proposed staging system for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|journal=Brain: A Journal of Neurology|volume=135|issue=Pt 3|pages=847–852|doi=10.1093/brain/awr351|issn=1460-2156|pmc=3286327|pmid=22271664}}</ref> while Milano-Torino Staging (MiToS) utilizes the subscores produced by the ALSFRS-R to define stages.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chiò|first=Adriano|last2=Hammond|first2=Edward R.|last3=Mora|first3=Gabriele|last4=Bonito|first4=Virginio|last5=Filippini|first5=Graziella|date=January 2015|title=Development and evaluation of a clinical staging system for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|journal=Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery, and Psychiatry|volume=86|issue=1|pages=38–44|doi=10.1136/jnnp-2013-306589|issn=1468-330X|pmid=24336810}}</ref>
== Questions == The questions used to determine an individuals ALSFRS-R score are listed below.<ref name=":2" /> {| class="wikitable" | colspan="2" |''1. Speech'' |- |4 |Normal speech processes |- |3 |Detectable speech disturbance |- |2 |Intelligible with repeating |- |1 |Speech combined with nonvocal communication |- |0 |Loss of useful speech |- | colspan="2" |''2. Salivation'' |- |4 |Normal |- |3 |Slight but definite excess of saliva in mouth; may have nighttime drooling |- |2 |Moderately excessive saliva; may have minimal drooling |- |1 |Marked excess of saliva with some drooling |- |0 |Marked drooling; requires constant tissue or handkerchief |- | colspan="2" |''3. Swallowing'' |- |4 |Normal eating habits |- |3 |Early eating problems — occasional choking |- |2 |Dietary consistency changes |- |1 |Needs supplemental tube feeding |- |0 |NPO (exclusively parenteral or enteral feeding) |- | colspan="2" |''4. Handwriting'' |- |4 |Normal |- |3 |Slow or sloppy: all words are legible |- |2 |Not all words are legible |- |1 |Able to grip pen but unable to write |- |0 |Unable to grip pen |- | colspan="2" |''5a. Cutting food and handling utensils (patients without gastrostomy)?'' |- |4 |Normal |- |3 |Somewhat slow and clumsy, but no help needed |- |2 |Can cut most foods, although clumsy and slow; some help needed |- |1 |Food must be cut by someone, but can still feed slowly |- |0 |Needs to be fed |- | colspan="2" |''5b. Cutting food and handling utensils(scale for patients with gastrostomy)?'' |- |4 |Normal |- |3 |Clumsy but able to perform all manipulations independently |- |2 |Some help needed with closures and fasteners |- |1 |Provides minimal assistance to caregiver |- |0 |Unable to perform any aspect of task |- | colspan="2" |''6. Dressing and hygiene'' |- |4 |Normal function |- |3 |Independent and complete self-care with effort or decreased efficiency |- |2 |Intermittent assistance or substitute methods |- |1 |Needs attendant for self-care |- |0 |Total dependence |- | colspan="2" |''7. Turning in bed and adjusting bed clothes'' |- |4 |Normal |- |3 |Somewhat slow and clumsy, but no help needed |- |2 |Can turn alone or adjust sheets, but with great difficulty |- |1 |Can initiate, but not turn or adjust sheets alone |- |0 |Helpless |- | colspan="2" |''8. Walking'' |- |4 |Normal |- |3 |Early ambulation difficulties |- |2 |Walks with assistance |- |1 |Nonambulatory functional movement |- |0 |No purposeful leg movement |- | colspan="2" |''9. Climbing stairs'' |- |4 |Normal |- |3 |Slow |- |2 |Mild unsteadiness or fatigue |- |1 |Needs assistance |- |0 |Cannot do |- | colspan="2" |''10. Dyspnea (new)'' |- |4 |None |- |3 |Occurs when walking |- |2 |Occurs with one or more of the following: eating, bathing, dressing (ADL) |- |1 |Occurs at rest, difficulty breathing when either sitting or lying |- |0 |Significant difficulty, considering using mechanical respiratory support |- | colspan="2" |''11. Orthopnea (new)'' |- |4 |None |- |3 |Some difficulty sleeping at night due to shortness of breath, |- | |does not routinely use more than two pillows |- |2 |Needs extra pillows in order to sleep (more than two) |- |1 |Can only sleep sitting up |- |0 |Unable to sleep |- | colspan="2" |''12. Respiratory insufficiency (new)'' |- |4 |None |- |3 |Intermittent use of BiPAP |- |2 |Continuous use of BiPAP during the night |- |1 |Continuous use of BiPAP during the night and day |- |0 |Invasive mechanical ventilation by intubation or tracheostomy |}

page.title: A Dictionary of the Chinese Language

revision.text:
{{Use Harvard referencing|date=December 2017}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox book | name = A Dictionary of the Chinese Language in Three Parts | image = MorrisonDCL.1815.0.pdf | caption = ''A Dictionary of the Chinese Language'', Part I, Vol. I, title page {{harvcol|Morrison|1815a}} | author = [[Robert Morrison (missionary)|Robert Morrison]] | country = [[Macau]] | language = Chinese, English | publisher = [[Peter Perring Thoms]] | pub_date = 1815-1823 | media_type = Print | pages = 4,595 | oclc = 500112156 }} '''''A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, in Three Parts''''' or '''''Morrison's Chinese dictionary''''' (1815-1823), compiled by the Anglo-Scottish [[missionary]] [[Robert Morrison (missionary)|Robert Morrison]] was the first Chinese-English, English-Chinese dictionary. Part I is Chinese-English arranged by the 214 [[Kangxi radical]]s, Part II is Chinese-English arranged alphabetically, and Part III is English-Chinese also arranged alphabetically. This groundbreaking [[reference work]] is enormous, comprising 4,595 pages in 6 [[quarto]] volumes and including 47,035 [[Headword|head]] [[Chinese character|characters]] taken from the 1716 ''[[Kangxi Dictionary]]''. However, Morrison's encyclopedic dictionary had flaws, notably failing to distinguish [[aspiration (phonetics)|aspirated]] consonants: the pronunciation ''taou'' is given for both aspirated ''táo'' ([[wikt:桃|桃]], "peach") and unaspirated ''dào'' ([[wikt:道|道]], "way; the [[Tao]]"). ==History== [[File:Morrison at work.jpg|thumb|right|200px|An engraving of [[George Chinnery]]'s lost ''Robert Morrison Translating the Bible'' ({{circa|lk=no|1828}}). [[Robert Morrison (missionary)|Morrison]] is assisted by [[Li Shigong]] (''left'') and [[Chen Laoyi]] (''right'').]] {{Main article| Robert Morrison (missionary)}} Robert Morrison (1782-1834) is credited with several historical firsts in addition to the first bidirectional Chinese and English dictionary. He was the first [[Protestant]] missionary in China, started the first Chinese-language [[periodical]] in 1815 {{harvcol|Wilkinson|2015|p=850}}, collaborated with [[William Milne (missionary)|William Milne]] to write the first [[Chinese Bible Translations|translation of the Bible into Chinese]] in 1823, helped to found the English-language ''[[The Canton Register]]'' in 1827, and compiled the first Western-language dictionary of a regional [[Varieties of Chinese|variety of Chinese]] {{harvcol|Morrison|1828}}. Morrison joined the [[London Missionary Society]] in 1804 and was chosen to lead a mission to China. They sent him to study at [[Gosport]] and introduced him to a young [[Cantonese]] man studying English in London: Robert Morrison transcribes his name as "Yong Sam Tak", Eliza Morrison as "Yung-san-tih" in "Mandarin" transcription {{harvcol|Morrison|1839|loc=[https://books.google.com/books?id=XRI6AAAAcAAJ&dq=Tsae%20a-keen&pg=PA217 Vol. I, p. 217].}}, and whose actual name was probably Rong Sande ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|容|三|德}}}}) {{harvcol|Strandenaes|2004|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=q0HBN4770MQC&pg=PA126 126–7]}}. In 1807, the LMS instructed Morrison to sail to [[Guangzhou]] (then known as "Canton") and continue studying until he had "accomplished [his] great object of acquiring the language", whereupon he would "turn this attainment into a direction which may be of extensive use to the world: perhaps you may have the honour of forming a Chinese Dictionary, more comprehensive and correct than any preceding one", as well as translating the Bible into Chinese {{harvcol|Morrison|1839|loc=Vol. I, p. 70}}. Upon his arrival in the [[Qing Empire]], Morrison learned that the Chinese were prohibited from teaching their language to foreigners, forcing him to [[Chinese as a foreign language|study Chinese]] secretly and hide his books from sight. Morrison eventually found two tutors, the scholar "Ko Seen-sang" and Abel Yun, who had learned [[Latin]] from [[Jesuit China missions|Catholic missionaries]]. Together, they began to translate the scriptures and compile the dictionary. In 1809, the [[East India Company]] employed Morrison as their translator, which legitimized his presence in Guangzhou's [[Thirteen Factories]] and provided sufficient income to continue working on the dictionary project and Bible translation. He translated and printed the [[Acts of the Apostles]] in 1810 and completed his Chinese Grammar in 1811. The situation worsened in 1812 when the [[Jiaqing Emperor]] issued an edict adding Christianity to the list of banned witchcrafts and superstitions, making the printing of Chinese-language books on the subject a capital crime {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=3}}. The LMS sent the missionary [[William Milne (missionary)|William Milne]] to assist Morrison in translating and printing the scriptures. In 1814, the East India Company sent the printing engineer [[Peter Perring Thoms]]. Together with Morrison's Chinese assistants such as [[Cai Gao]] and [[Liang Fa]], he created the Chinese character font for the dictionary. Morrison worked on producing ''A Dictionary of the Chinese Language'' for more than 15 years with "extraordinary perseverance, industry, and ingenuity" {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=5}}. Morrison described the bilingual Chinese dictionaries that he used as sources for his own lexicographical work: "several MS. Dictionaries of the old Missionaries, in English and French, and, latterly, the printed copy of Father Basil's Dictionary" {{harvcol|Morrison|1839|Vol. II, p. 454}}. This refers to the 9,000-entry 1698 ''Dictionarium Sino-Latinum'' manuscript of the [[Italians|Italian]] [[Franciscan Order|Franciscan]] Basilio Brollo or de Glemona (1648-1704), which the French orientalist [[Joseph de Guignes]] (1759-1845) translated as the 1813 ''{{lang|fr|Dictionnaire Chinois, Français et Latin}}'' without any attribution to the original author {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=306}}. Brollo's innovation was to provide a Chinese character dictionary alphabetically collated by transliteration, with a user-friendly index arranged by radicals and strokes, successfully combining Chinese and European lexicographic traditions {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=313}}. This lexicographical macrostructure was adopted in Morrison's dictionary, and most bilingual Chinese dictionaries up to the present day. The first volume of Morrison's Chinese dictionary was published in 1815 and the last in 1823. All 6 volumes were printed by {{nowrap|P. P. Thoms}} in [[Portuguese Macao|Macao]] and published and sold by Black, Parbury, & Allen, the booksellers to the East India Company. The dictionary was printed in a run of 750 copies at a total cost of [[GBP|₤]]10,440 {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=300}} or ₤12,000 {{harvcol|Broomhall|1927|p=173}}; they sold for the "princely sum" of 20 [[Guinea (coin)|guineas]] {{harvcol|Wilkinson|2015|p=84}}. The LMS was unable to subsidize the entire project, but the directors of the East India Company agreed to pay because they recognized the dictionary's incalculable benefit, not only to missionaries but also to their own employees {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=5}}. The later volumes were published simultaneously in London by Kingsbury, Parbury, & Allen or by Black, Parbury, & Allen. The ''Dictionary of the Chinese Language'' marked a new era in the compilation and publication of bilingual Chinese works. Before the 19th century, Catholic missionaries such as Basilio Brollo had compiled many bilingual manuscript dictionaries, but their circulation was inevitably restricted by the difficulties of copying a dictionary by hand. The initial edition of 750 copies and subsequent reprints enabled Morrison's dictionary to reach a wider readership and have a far more profound impact {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=316}}. {| class="wikitable" |+ Publication history {{harvcol|Ryu|2009|p=7}} |- ! Part !! Volume !! Year of Publication !! Pages !! (+ Preface) |- | rowspan="3" | I || [https://archive.org/stream/b2201178x_0001#page/n6/mode/1up I] || 1815|| 930 || + 20 |- | [https://archive.org/stream/b2201178x_0002#page/n6/mode/1up II] || 1822|| colspan="2" | 884 |- | [https://archive.org/stream/b2201178x_0003#page/n6/mode/1up III] || 1823|| colspan="2" | 908 |- | rowspan="2" | II || [https://archive.org/stream/b2201178x_0004#page/n6/mode/1up I] || 1819|| 1,090 || + 20 |- | [https://archive.org/stream/b2201178x_0005#page/n6/mode/1up II] || 1820|| 483 || + 6 |- | colspan="2" | [https://archive.org/stream/b2201178x_0006#page/n6/mode/1up III] || 1822 || 480 || + 5 |} Morrison's dictionary is composed of three parts or six [[quarto]] ({{convert|306|x|242|mm|sp=us|abbr=on|disp=or}}) volumes published in different years. Part I has 3 volumes with Volume I published in 1815 containing 18 pages in the preface, 930 pages in the dictionary proper, and 2 additional pages consisting of advertisements {{harvcol|Morrison|1815a}}. Volume II, published in 1822, is composed of 884 pages {{harvcol|Morrison|1822a}}, and Volume III, published in 1823, is composed of 908 pages {{harvcol|Morrison|1823}}. Part II has two volumes: Volume I published in 1819 contains 20 pages in the preface and 1,090 pages in the dictionary proper {{harvcol|Morrison|1819}}, and Volume II published in 1820 contains 6 pages in the preface, 178 pages in the first section, and 305 pages in the second section of the dictionary proper {{harvcol|Morrison|1820}}. Part III was published in 1822 with only one volume containing 5 pages in the preface and 480 pages in the dictionary proper {{harvcol|Morrison|1822b}}{{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=6}}. The publication of Morrison's dictionary attracted the attention of scholars worldwide, and Part II was reprinted from 1865 until 1913. The revised preface says the second part "has been generally commended by experienced Sinologues as the most perfect and useful of the whole" {{harvcol|Morrison|1865|p=i}}. In 1865, the London Mission Press in [[Shanghai International Settlement|Shanghai]] and [[Trubner and Co|Trubner & Co.]] in London first republished Part II in 2 volumes, totaling 1630 pages. In 1913, [[Zhonghua Book Company]] reprinted Part II in a pocketbook size, which made it much more affordable and easier to carry {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=6}}. Morrison's lexicographical legacy is reflected in two facts: his dictionary's macrostructure and microstructure became the model for many later Chinese-English dictionaries, and his transliteration system was adopted as the basis for [[Wade-Giles]] [[romanization of Chinese|romanization]] {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=321}}. Morrison's Chinese dictionary became the prototype for other 19th-century works. The English [[Congregational church|Congregationalist]] missionary and Bible translator [[Walter Henry Medhurst]] compiled the 1842 and 1847 ''Chinese and English Dictionary: Containing all the Words in the Chinese Imperial Dictionary, Arranged According to the Radicals''. Medhurst claimed this was an original translation based on the ''[[Kangxi Zidian]]'', but it was in fact just an edited abridgment of Morrison's dictionary, a "plagiarism rather than an original compilation" {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=318}}. The American sinologist and missionary [[Samuel Wells Williams]] compiled the 1874 ''[[A Syllabic Dictionary of the Chinese Language|Syllabic Dictionary of the Chinese Language]]'', whose Chinese title ({{lang|zh|漢英韻府}}) echoed that of Part II of Morrison's work ({{lang|zh|五車韻府}}). The preface says that although many similar Chinese-English dictionaries by Medhurst, [[Elijah Coleman Bridgman]], and others were published in small numbers, they became "very scarce, while the number of students has increased tenfold", and learners of Chinese relied on reprints of Morrison {{harvcol|Williams|1874|p=v}}. Williams explicitly identified "Dr. Medhurst's translation of the K'anghi Tsz'tien" as a more important source for his own work than Morrison's dictionary {{harvcol|Williams|1874|p=vi}}. The British diplomat and sinologist [[Herbert Giles]] edited ''[[A Chinese-English Dictionary]]'', published in 1892 and 1912. Giles praised Morrison as "the great pioneer" of Chinese-English lexicography, but criticized his failure to mark aspiration. He said Medhurst "attempted aspirates" but omitted some and wrongly inserted others. While Williams correctly marked aspiration and tones, Giles says "he provided too few phrases, and mistranslated a large number of those" {{harvcol|Giles|1892|pp=vii-viii}}. Ironically, Yang's textual analysis finds that Giles's dictionary is more closely linked to Williams's than to Morrison's {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=318}}. Morrison's Chinese dictionary introduced a systematic transliteration system that was used for over four decades until it was replaced by [[Thomas Francis Wade]]'s [[Wade romanization|romanization scheme]] in 1867; that became the basis for the [[Wade-Giles]] system of 1892-1912, which was widely used and still survives alongside [[pinyin]] romanization. Morrison's system was almost forgotten after being replaced by Wade romanization, but [[James Legge]] adopted it virtually unchanged into the [[Legge romanization]] used in his ''Chinese Classics'' series {{harvcol|Legge|1861–1872}}{{harvcol|Coblin|2003|p=355}}. Morrison's romanization system influenced the Wade, Legge, and Wade-Giles schemes {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=313}}. Robert Morrison's dictionary is still in use two hundred years after its publication. For example, the American sinologist [[W. South Coblin]] analyzed Morrison's romanization of Mandarin for clues about the pronunciation of early 19th-century standard Chinese {{harvcol|Coblin|2003}}. Morrison's pronunciation glosses followed the lower Yangtze [[Koiné language|koiné]] as the standard [[Mandarin (late imperial lingua franca)|Mandarin]] of the time, "what the Chinese call the [[Nanjing dialect|Nanking Dialect]], than the [[Beijing dialect|Peking]]" {{harvcol|Morrison|1815a|p=xviii}}{{harvcol|Morrison|1815b|p=x}}. ==Content== The title pages of the dictionary's parts give two versions of the full title. Part I's title page (shown above) reads "Part the First; Containing Chinese and English, Arranged According to the Radicals; Part the Second; Chinese and English, Arranged Alphabetically; and Part the Third, English and Chinese". The title pages of Part II and Part iii read "Part the First, Containing Chinese and English Arranged According to the Keys; Part the Second, Chinese and English Arranged Alphabetically, and Part the Third, Consisting of English and Chinese". Each part of the dictionary is a complete and independent unit in itself {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=6}}. {{anchor|I|Part I|A Dictionary of the Chinese Language}} ===Part I: A Dictionary of the Chinese Language=== [[File:MorrisonDCL.1823.513.pdf|thumb|300px|The entry on {{lang|zh|{{linktext|道}}}} ("Taou", now ''dào'') in Part I of Morrison's dictionary {{harvcol|Morrison|1823|p=513}}. The original did not include [[Chinese tones|tone]] marks, but a reader has added it to this entry.]] Part I, '''''A Dictionary of the Chinese Language''''', is supertitled in Chinese—but not English—as a "[[Chinese character|character]] dictionary" ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|字典}}}}). It was a Chinese-to-English dictionary, organized by the [[Kangxi radical|214 radical system]] employed by the 1716 ''[[Kangxi Dictionary]]''. These [[Chinese radical|radicals]] are the initial or major graphic components of [[Chinese characters]], ranging from 1 to 17 [[Stroke (CJKV character)|strokes]]. In Morrison's dictionary, Volume I starts with [[Radical 1]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|一}}}}, "one") and ends at [[Radical 41]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|寸}}}} ("thumb; [[Chinese inch]]") {{harvcol|Morrison|1815a}}; Volume II starts with [[Radical 42]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|小}}}}, "small") and stops at [[Radical 119]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|米}}}}, "rice") {{harvcol|Morrison|1822}}; and Volume III begins with [[Radical 120]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|糸}}}}, "silk") and ends the dictionary with [[Radical 214]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|龠}}}}, "flute") {{harvcol|Morrison|1823}}. Vols. II & III were published simultaneously in London by Kingsbury, Parbury, & Allen. Morrison acknowledged his debt to the ''Kangxi Dictionary'' in his introduction to Volume I, saying it "forms the ground work" of Part I {{harvcol|Morrison|1815a|p=ix}}, including its arrangement, number of characters (47,035), and many of its definitions and examples {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=313}}. However, it also differed in significant ways. Chinese scholars have found that the majority of the Kangxi dictionary's usage examples were taken from books before the 10th century and ignored vulgar forms and expressions. Morrison also noticed this and chose examples better suited to his intended readership {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=315}}, adding vulgar, humorous, colloquial, and modern examples. For instance {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=9}}, Morrison included descriptions for {{lang|zh|{{linktext|王八}}}} (''wángba'', "tortoise" but also "cuckold; son of a bitch; pimp") and {{lang|zh|{{linktext|烏龜}}}} (''wūguī'', "tortoise" but also "cuckold") as "terms of abuse, denoting one who lives on his wife's prostitution; one lost to virtue". Similarly {{lang|zh|{{linktext|王八蛋}}}} (''wángbadàn'', "turtle egg" but also "son of a bitch") as "a bastard, in opprobrious language" {{harvcol|Morrison|1815a|p=188}}. Morrison's dictionary also gives Chinese usage examples and quotations from a wide range of sources, including classical literature, law, medicine, novels, and numerous unidentified contemporary sources. His [[Chinese calligraphy|orthographic standard]] for the dictionary's "Radicals, and of the large Characters throughout the work," was said to have been "taken from an excellent Dictionary" {{harvcol|Morrison|1815|p=1}}. This was either [[Sha Mu]]'s 1787 ''Yiwen Beilan'' ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|藝|文|備覽}}}}, "Literary Writings for Consultation", or ''E-wǎn-pe-lan'' in Sha's romanization) or its 1807 reprint. Morrison's copy is now located at the [[University of London]]'s [[SOAS, University of London#Library|SOAS Library]]. A comparative study of its annotations confirms its influence, although this remained less marked than that of the ''Kangxi Dictionary'' {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=312}}. Philosophically, Morrison's dictionary departed from that ordered by the [[Kangxi Emperor]] by including not only the [[Confucianism|Confucian]] [[Four Books and Five Classics]] but many more items drawn from [[Taoism|Taoist]] and [[Chinese Buddhism|Buddhist]] texts. [[Yang Huiling|Yang]] uses the example of the dictionary's first entry, {{lang|zh|{{linktext|一}}}} (''yi'', "one") {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=316}}, which notes
The Secl [Sect] Taou affirms, that {{lang|zh|道生一一生二二生三三生萬物…}} "Taou produced one, one produced two, two produced three, and three produced all things." If it be asked, what then is Taou? They reply, 靜極乃道也… "Extreme quiescence, or a state of perfect stillness is Taou." The Three, when speaking of their external appearance, they call {{lang|zh|天之秀氣地之生氣感和風之清氣…}} "The heaven's adorning principle, earth's life giving principle, and the pure principle of the exciting harmonizing wind"; or as they define it, "That aerial principle, or influence, by which the heavens and earth act on each other." The internal Three, they call {{lang|zh|氣之清神之靈精之潔靜裏分陰陽而精氣神同化於虛無…}} "The clear unmixed influence, the intelligence of spirit; the purity of essence; in the midst of quiescence separated the Yin and Yang. Essence, influence and spirit, together operated in a state of vacuum." (Taou tĭh king). Their notions of the great One Cause of all things, are very fanciful and obscure {{harvcol|Morrison|1815a|pp=12–3}}.
The first quote is from ''[[Tao Te Ching]]'' (Ch. 42) and the others from commentaries. The first volume of Part I and its two companion volumes were written in notably different styles. Volume I is "notoriously abundant" in encyclopedic examples and quotations, while the other two volumes of Part I just provide brief definitions and a few examples {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=314}}. When Morrison published the first volume of Part I in 1815 after 8 years of hard work, he realized that if he tried to compile the rest of the dictionary on such a comprehensive scale, he might not finish the dictionary in his lifetime. He then changed course and rapidly published Part II in 1819 and 1820. His dictionary's alphabetically arranged Part II, with concise definitions and brief usage examples, proved to be more useful for learners of Chinese but lacked the rich quotations that made the first volume of Part I a model of an "encyclopedic and culturally rich bilingual dictionary" {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=315}}. To illustrate Volume I's "grand scope" and "many surprises", Wu Xian & al. cited the 40-page entry for {{lang|zh|{{linktext|學}}}} (''xue'', "study; receive instruction; practice; imitate; learn; a place of studying") {{harvcol|Morrison|1815a|pp=746–85}} whose usage examples and illustrations range across the traditional [[Chinese educational system]] from "private school" ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|學館}}}}, ''xueguan'') to "government-run [[prefecture (China)|prefectural]] school" ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|府學}}}}, ''fuxue''), explain the [[imperial examination]] civil service system from "county candidates" ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|秀才}}}}, ''xiucai'') to "members of the imperial [[Hanlin Academy]]" ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|翰林}}}}, ''hanlin''), and include a variety of related terms and passages such as 100 rules for schools, details on examination systems, and a list of books for classical study. They conclude that the dictionary's "richness of information was unprecedented" {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=10}}. An example of a later entry is {{lang|zh|{{linktext|道}}}} (''dào'', "way") in Volume III {{harvcol|Morrison|1823|p=513}}. It is given with his [[Chinese tones|atonal]] romanization "TAOU" under [[Radical 162]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|辵}}}}, "walk"), with the [[roman numeral]] IX noting that it has nine [[Stroke (CJKV character)|strokes]] beyond those of the base radical. The [[regular script]] character and pronunciation are given alongside its [[small seal script|small seal]] and [[cursive script (East Asia)|cursive]] forms, followed by English translations, derived terms, and usage examples. In this case, the word is glossed as "A way; a path; being at the head; the way that leads to; a thoroughfare on all sides. A principle. The principle from which heaven, earth, man, and all nature emanates." Of the 22 words and usages given, the first six are medical terms (e.g., "Seaou pëen taou {{lang|zh|{{linktext|小便道}}}} the urinary passage; the vagina") and the last thirteen are [[circuit (administrative division)|administrative circuit]]s of imperial China (e.g., "{{lang|zh|{{linktext|河南|道}}}} [[Henan|Ho-nan]] taou") The other three are notice of the [[Daoguang Emperor]]'s [[Chinese era names|era name]] ("Taou-kwang yuen nëen {{lang|zh|{{linktext|道光|元|年}}}} the first of Taoukwang, 'reason's glory,' title of the reigning emperor of China (A.D. 1821)"); the common word ''[[wikt:道喜|dàoxǐ]]'' ("Taou he {{lang|zh|{{linktext|道喜}}}} to congratulate, an expression used amongst equals"); and a citation from [[Confucius]]'s ''[[Analects]]'' ("Taou tsëen shing che kwǒ {{lang|zh|{{linktext|道|千|乘|之|國}}}} To rule or govern a nation that can send forth a thousand [[Chinese chariot|war chariots]]"). {{anchor|II|Part II|Chinese and English Arranged Alphabetically}} ===Part II: A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, Arranged Alphabetically=== [[File:MorrisonDCL.1819.820.pdf|thumb|300px|The entry on {{lang|zh|{{linktext|道}}}} ("Taou", now ''dào'') in Part II of Morrison's dictionary {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=820}}.]] [[File:MorrisonDCL.1820.229.pdf|thumb|300px|A page of script variants for {{lang|zh|{{linktext|道}}}} ("Taou", now ''dào'') from Part II of Morrison's dictionary {{harvcol|Morrison|1820|p=229}}.]] Part II, '''''A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, Arranged Alphabetically''''', is supertitled in Chinese—but not English—as a ''Wuche Yunfu'' ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|五車|韻府}}}}, "Erudition Phonetic Dictionary"). The name literally means a "five-cart[loads of books, a classical idiom for "erudite"] storehouse of euphony", and copies the title of an earlier [[rime dictionary]] compiled by [[Chen Jinmo]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|陳|藎|謨}}}}) and [[Han Yihu]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|含|一|胡}}}}), who gave its unpublished manuscript to the editors of the ''Kangxi Dictionary''. They made extensive use of it, with definitions often identical in both works {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=v}}. Morrison claimed to have worked from Chen and Han's dictionary, rearranging its roughly 40,000 characters according to [[syllabary|syllables]] instead of pronunciations and tones {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|pp=v–vi}} with the help of the ''Fenyun'' ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|分|韻}}}}, "Divisions of Rimes") and Basilio Brollo's dictionary, as well as contemporary words from elsewhere. This work took about seven years {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=7}}. Yang's comparative study of Parts I and II found, however, that the definitions of both are clearly based on the ''Kangxi Dictionary'' and reflect little content from original ''Wuche Yunfu'' {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=312}}. Part II is in two volumes. In Volume I, the preface explains the dictionary's composition, purpose and orthography and the main section is a "Syllabic Dictionary" in which [[Romanization of Chinese|romanized]] Chinese words are collated in [[alphabetical order]] {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|pp=1-1065}}. In Volume II, the first section contains a table of the [[Kangxi radical|214 ''Kangxi'' radicals]], a [[Collation#Radical-and-stroke sorting|radical-and-stroke]] index of the characters in Volume I, and an English-to-Chinese index of words that gives the character numbers in Volume I {{harvcol|Morrison|1820|pp=iii–179}}. The second independent section "A Synopsis of Various Forms of the Chinese Character" giving the [[regular script]], [[semi-cursive script]], [[Cursive script (East Asia)|cursive script]], [[clerical script]], [[Small Seal Script|small seal script]], and [[bronze script]] forms of various [[Chinese character|characters]] {{harvcol|Morrison|1820|pp=1–305}}. Part II of the dictionary contains 12,674 character entries, far fewer than the 47,035 entries in Part I {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=313}}. On the other hand, it continued to provide an estimated 20,000 examples and Chinese quotations in Chinese characters, accompanied with romanization and English translations, a vast improvement over earlier dictionaries without examples or Basilio Brollo's Chinese–Latin dictionaries, which presented its examples only in romanization {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=314}}. Vol. I was only published in Macao, but Vol. II was published simultaneously at London by Black, Parbury, & Allen. The preface notes Morrison's intent: "The Author's object has been, and the intention of the Dictionary ought to be, to communicate the Language to ''Europeans''." {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=viii}}. Its content is wide-ranging. "There are beautiful pieces of poetry, interesting and instructive portions of History and Biography; and important Moral Maxims, in Chinese that is a language amongst the ''most ancient'' and the ''most extensively'' known on earth,… it is the ''living language'' of five nations, which together, constitute one third of the mankind." Wu and Zheng say, "Far more than a mere dictionary of the Chinese language, Morrison's dictionary is a history book, a biography, a collection of idiomatic expressions and common sayings of the Chinese people, and, last but not least, full of the Christian evangelical message expressed in many ways." {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=7}}, In both Part I{{harvcol|Morrison|1815a|p=ix}} and II {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=37}}, discussion of paper ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|紙}}}}) occasions discussion of its invention by [[Cai Lun]], although his name appears as both "Tsae Lun" or "Tsae-lun" and one entry mistakenly places him in the 10th century {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=37}} instead of the 1st. Another example is the entry on {{lang|zh|{{linktext|猜}}}} (''cāi'', "guess; suspect"), which occasions a digression on a Chinese drinking game: "{{lang|zh|{{linktext|猜拳}}}} to guess the number of fingers thrown out, or stretched straight from a previously folded hand, which is a drunken amusement of the Chinese. When the opponent guesses the right number of fingers thrown out, at the instant he speaks, he wins, and the person throwing out his fingers has to drink as a forfeit." {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=8}}. Part II—unlike Part I—includes notation regarding Chinese tones. Unfortunately, Morrison transcribed the [[Four tones (Middle Chinese)|four tone distinctions]] of [[Middle Chinese]] rhyme dictionaries rather than [[Chinese tones|those]] of [[modern Chinese]]. The romanizations of Part II are left unmarked for a "level" tone ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|平}}}}, ''píng''), given a [[grave accent]] (e.g., à) for a "rising" tone ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|上}}}}, ''shǎng''), given an [[acute accent]] (e.g., á) for a "departing" tone ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|去}}}}, ''qù''), and a [[breve]] (e.g., ǎ) for an "entering" tone. By the time Morrison was composing his dictionary, the old level tone had begun dividing into modern Mandarin's [[first tone (Mandarin)|high]] and [[second tone (Mandarin)|rising]] tones; the old rising tone had begun dividing into the modern [[third tone (Mandarin)|third]] and [[fourth tone (Mandarin)|falling]] tones;{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} and the entering tone had ceased to exist {{harvcol|Norman|1988|p=173}}. Only the old departing tone continued to exist, as the modern falling tone. (In other dialects of Chinese, such as [[Cantonese language|Cantonese]], these tones developed separately{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} but Morrison employed the [[Nanjing dialect]] of his era's [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]].) {{harvcol|Morrison|1815a|p=xviii}}{{harvcol|Morrison|1815b|p=x}}. Part II also includes etymological glosses of the formation of the Chinese characters. Although these were often (inaccurate) guesses or [[folk etymology|folk etymologies]], they helped students of Chinese as a second language to comprehend and memorize characters. Wu Xian & al. draw attention to his treatment of the character {{lang|zh|{{linktext|仰}}}} (''yǎng'', "look up; admire"), which now consists of [[Radical 9]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|人}}}}, "person") and {{lang|zh|{{linktext|卬}}}} (''áng'', "high") {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=7}}. Morrison wrote, "YANG 仰, from ''man'' and ''to look upwards''. To raise the head and look upwards with expectation or desire..." {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=994}}. Two subsequent centuries of study and archeological discoveries have greatly increased understanding of how Chinese characters originated. It is now established that "Originally {{lang|zh|卬}} depicted a person standing next to {{lang|zh|卩}} (''jié'') a person kneeling. Another {{lang|zh|{{linktext|亻}}}} ({{lang|zh|人}} ''rén'') person was added later, forming {{lang|zh|仰}}." {{harvcol|Wenlin Institute|2016|p=}}. The entry for {{lang|zh|{{linktext|道}}}} in the second part of Morrison's dictionary gives a graphic variant {{lang|zh|{{linktext|衟}}}}, the entry number 9945, the acute accent [[four tones (Middle Chinese)|"departing" tone]], the character origin "From ''to walk'' and ''head''", translation equivalents, and 12 usage examples. The English translation runs:
A way; a path; being at the head; the way that leads to; a thoroughfare on all sides. A principle. The priuciple {{sic}} from which heaven, earth, man, and all nature emanates. Le {{lang|zh|理}} is a latent principle; Tanu {{sic}} is a principle in action. Correct, virtuous principles and course of action. Order and good principles in a government and country. A word; to speak; to say; the way or cause from or by which; to direct; to lead in the way. To accord with or go in a course pointed out. The name of a country. Used by the Buddhists for a particular state of existence, whether amongst human beings or amongst brutes {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=820}}.
The usage examples include words from [[Taoism]] and [[Chinese Buddhism|Buddhism]]: "Taou {{lang|zh|道}} in the [[Tao Te Ching|books]] of [[Lao-tse|Laou-tsze]] is very like the ''Eternal Reason'' of which some Europeans speak; ''{{lang|la|Ratio}}'' of the [[Ancient Rome|Latins]], and the ''[[Logos]]'' of the [[Ancient Greeks|Greeks]]."; and using ''zhì'' ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|帙}}}}, "cloth case for a book"), "Taou těë {{lang|zh|道帙}} a certificate by which the priests of Buddha are entitled to three days provision at every temple they go to." {{anchor|III|Part III|An English and Chinese Dictionary}} ===Part III: An English and Chinese Dictionary=== Part III, '''''An English and Chinese Dictionary''''', was given without a Chinese supertitle. It comprises Morrison's English-to-Chinese dictionary and is arranged [[English alphabet|alphabetically]] from "A" ("A, {{lang|zh|英文音母碎字之第一}} Ying wǎn, yin moo suy tsze che te yǐh, The first letter of the English Alphabet.") {{harvcol|Morrison|1822b|p=1}} to "Zone" ("ZONE, a [[Zone (vestment)|girdle]], {{lang|zh|帶子}} tae tsze; {{lang|zh|圍帶}} wei tai.") {{harvcol|Morrison|1822b|p=480}}. It was printed simultaneously in London by Black, Parbury, & Allen. Its entries are terser than those of the Chinese volumes, particularly Part I, Volume 1. The entry for "way" is "WAY, road, or path, {{lang|zh|路}} loo; {{lang|zh|道}} taou; {{lang|zh|途}} too. A method or means, {{lang|zh|法}} fa" {{harvcol|Morrison|1822b|463}}. The fraught issue of [[Chinese names for the God of Abrahamic religions|Chinese names for God]] occasioned a somewhat fuller treatment:
'''GOD''' or the Deus of the Chinese was originally, and is still most generally {{lang|zh|{{linktext|神}}}} [[Shen (Chinese religion)|Shin]]; in the plural, Dii, {{lang|zh|{{linktext|神鬼}}}} Shin kwei, and {{lang|zh|{{linktext|神祇}}}} Shin ke. A sort of Supreme God, is in the ancient books expressed by {{lang|zh|{{linktext|上帝}}}} [[shangdi|Shang-te]]. [[genius (spirit)|Genii]] of particular places are also expressed by {{lang|zh|{{linktext|神}}}} Shin, as {{lang|zh|{{linktext|河神}}}} ho shin, God of the river; {{lang|zh|{{linktext|山神}}}} shan shin, god of the hill, &c. All these gods are in Chinese notions inferior to {{lang|zh|{{linktext|天}}}} [[tian|Ten]], Heaven {{harvcol|Morrison|1822b|pp=189–90}}.
==Reception== Robert Morrison's Chinese-English dictionary has received both blame and praise. Considering that he was a self-taught lexicographer who compiled a dictionary of such a colossal size and scope, working with assistants who did not speak English, it would inevitably fall short of perfection, such the typographical errors and misprints noted above. Within his lifetime, the publication of Morrison's Chinese dictionary did not bring him universal acclaim, but instead triggered a controversy as to the authorship {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=300}}. In 1818 and again in 1830, the German orientalist [[Julius Klaproth]] accused Morrison of merely translating Chinese dictionaries rather than compiling a new or original one {{harvcol|Klaproth|1818}}{{harvcol|Klaproth|1830}}. In response to Klaproth's challenges, Morrison wrote an 1831 letter to the ''Asiatic Journal'' that describes the dictionary's compilation in detail.
I know of no better way of writing a Dictionary of any language, than that which I pursued; namely, to make use of all the native Dictionaries I could collect, with the original books referred to in them; to employ native scholars to assist me in consulting those several works, and in ascertaining their exact meaning... In the whole of the work, there was no mere copying from one book into another; no mere translation from one language into another; but an exercise of judgment and choice, throughout: and if any man may be called the author of a Dictionary, Morrison may justly be called the author of the Dictionary attributed to him. {{harvcol|Morrison|1839|loc=Vol. II, pp. 453-454}}
In retrospect, a "major flaw" in Morrison's dictionary is the failure to distinguish the [[phonemic contrast]] between [[aspirated consonant|aspirated]] and unaspirated consonants {{harvcol|Coblin|2003|p=352}}. [[Herbert Giles]]'s ''Chinese-English Dictionary'' says Morrison's 1819 volume gave no aspirates, "a defect many times worse" than would be omitting the [[rough breathing]] in a Greek lexicon, and Medhurst's 1843 edition attempted aspirates, but omitted many and wrongly inserted others {{harvcol|Giles|1892|p=vii}}. [[Samuel Wells Williams]]'s 1874 ''[[A Syllabic Dictionary of the Chinese Language|Syllabic Dictionary]]'' was apparently the first dictionary to get this distinction sorted out {{harvcol|Norman|1988|p=173}}. Another flaw is Morrison's treatment of some characters that have more than one pronunciation and meaning: {{lang|zh|{{linktext|臭}}}} means "foul; stinking; disgusting; disgraceful" when pronounced ''chòu'' but simply "odor; smell; scent" when read ''xiù'' {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=9}}. Morrison listed both senses with the first pronunciation and treated it as similar to the neutral and disagreeable senses of the English "smell":
'''{{lang|zh|臭}} Chow''' Smell or flavor generally; scent; offensive smell; disagreeable odours; fume or effluvia. Stink; to smell; that which is morally offensive. The character is formed from Keuen {{lang|zh|{{linktext|犬}}}} A dog, in allusion to that animal finding its way by the scent. {{lang|zh|{{linktext|香臭}}}} Heang chow, a fragrant smell; {{lang|zh|{{linktext|惡臭}}}} Gŏ chow, a bad smell; {{lang|zh|{{linktext|遺|臭|萬|年}}}} E chow wan nëen, to leave an eternal reproach on one's name; {{lang|zh|{{linktext|其|臭|如|蘭}}}} Ko chow joo lan, it smells fragrant as the [[orchid|Lan-flower]]. {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=94}}
In these derived terms, the negative senses would be read ''chòu'', but the pleasant "fragrant as an orchid" would use the pronunciation ''xiù''. Another example is when he takes the {{lang|zh|{{linktext|郎}}}} in {{lang|zh|{{linktext|招|郎|入|室}}}} to mean "bride" {{harvcol|Morrison|1819|p=23}} when the intended sense is a "bridegroom" being invited to live with his in-laws {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=10}}. On the other hand, Morrison's Chinese dictionary has won critical acclaims from scholars all over the world since the publication of the first volume in 1815. Alexander Leith Ross wrote to Morrison that his dictionary had an extensive circulation in Europe, and would be "an invaluable treasure to every student of Chinese" {{harvcol|Morrison|1839|loc=Vol. I, p. 494}}. The French sinologist [[Stanislas Julien]] described Part II as "without dispute, the best Chinese Dictionary composed in a European language" {{harvcol|Morrison|1865|p=i}}. The American missionary William A. Macy said all the missionaries and scholars of Chinese had used Morrison's dictionary as the "common fountain" from which they could "obtain the knowledge they desired" {{harvcol|Macy|1860|p=568}}. One modern scholar calls Morrison's dictionary "the greatest achievement of any researcher of Chinese" {{harvcol|Ryu|2009|p=9}}. Another describes the comprehensive bilingual dictionary compilation and publication project as "unprecedented and unsurpassed in 19th-century China" {{harvcol|Yang|2014|p=303}}. Wu and Zheng say Morrison's was the first widely used Chinese-English dictionary and has served as a "milestone in the early promotion of communications between China and the West" {{harvcol|Wu and Zheng|2009|p=3}}. A recent book on Chinese lexicography says that although Morrison's dictionary "contained numerous errors" when examined from a modern perspective, "the dictionary delineated the basic configuration of a bilingual dictionary and shed a good deal of light upon the design and compilation of English-Chinese, Chinese-English, and other bilingual dictionary types" {{harvcol|Yong and Peng|2008|p=386}}. Morrison's obituary notice summarizes his dedication and contribution to the world, "In efforts to make this [Chinese] language known to foreigners and chiefly to the English, he has done more than any other man living or dead." {{harvcol|Anon.|1835|p=178}}. ==Editions== * {{citation |last=Morrison |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Morrison (missionary) |date=1815 |url=https://archive.org/details/p1dictionaryofch01morruoft |title=''字典'' A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, in Three Parts, ''Vol. I.—Part I.'' |publisher=East India Company's Press |location=Macao }}. * {{citation |last=Morrison |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Morrison (missionary) |date=1822 |url=https://archive.org/details/p1dictionaryofch02morruoft |title=''字典'' A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, in Three Parts, ''Vol. II.—Part I.'' |publisher=East India Company's Press |location=Macao }}. * {{citation |last=Morrison |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Morrison (missionary) |date=1823 |url=https://archive.org/details/p1dictionaryofch03morruoft |title=''字典'' A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, in Three Parts, ''Vol. III.—Part I.'' |publisher=East India Company's Press |location=Macao }}. * {{citation |last=Morrison |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Morrison (missionary) |date=1819 |url=https://archive.org/details/p2dictionaryofch01morruoft |title=''五車韻府'' A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, in Three Parts, ''Part II.—Vol. I.'' |publisher=East India Company's Press |location=Macao }}. * {{citation |last=Morrison |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Morrison (missionary) |date=1820 |url=https://archive.org/details/p2dictionaryofch02morruoft |title=''五車韻府'' A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, in Three Parts, ''Part II.—Vol. II.'' |publisher=East India Company's Press |location=Macao }}. * {{citation |last=Morrison |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Morrison (missionary) |date=1822 |url=https://archive.org/details/p2dictionaryofch03morruoft |title=A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, in Three Parts, ''Part III.'' |publisher=East India Company's Press |location=Macao }}. * {{citation |last=Morrison |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Morrison (missionary) |date=1865 |url=https://archive.org/details/dictionaryofchin00morr |title=''五車韻府'' A Dictionary of the Chinese Language, ''Vol. I.'' |publisher=London Mission Press |location=Shanghai }}, a reprint of Part II. * {{citation |last=Morrison |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Morrison (missionary) |date=1913 |title=A Dictionary of the Chinese Language... |publisher=Zhonghua Book Co. }}, a reprint of Part II. ==References== * {{citation |author=Anonymous |date=1835 |ref={{harvcolid|Anon.|1835}} |contribution=Obituary of Dr. Morrison |url=https://archive.org/details/chinesereposito05unkngoog |title=Chinese Repository, ''Vol. III'' |pp=176–84 }}. * {{citation |last=Broomhall |first=Marshall Press }}. * {{citation |last=Ryu |first=Hyun-Guk |date=2009 |contribution-url=http://designhistoryforum.org/dd/papers/vol04/no2/04_2_1.pdf |contribution=Robert Morrison's Influence on Translation, |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q0HBN4770MQC&printsec=frontcover |editor=Stephen Batalden |editor2=Kathleen Cann |editor3=John Dean |display-editors=0 |publisher=Sheffield Phoenix Press |date=2004 |contribution=Anonymous Bible Translators: Native Literati and the Translation of the Bible into Chinese, 1807–1907 |last=Strandenaes |first=Thor |pp=121–48 }}. * {{citation |last=Wilkinson |first=Endymion |date=2015 |title=Chinese History: A New Manual, ''4th ed.'' |location=[[Cambridge, Mass.|Cambridge]] |publisher=Harvard University Asia Center }}. * {{citation |last=Williams |first=Samuel Wells |authorlink=Samuel Wells Williams |date=1874 |title=[[A Syllabic Dictionary of the Chinese Language]] |location=Shanghai |publisher=Shanghai American Presbyterian Mission Press }}. * {{citation |last=Wenlin Institute |first= |date=2016|title=[[Wenlin Software for Learning Chinese]] |publisher= Wenlin Institute}}. * {{citation |last=Wu |first=Xian |authormask=Wu Xian revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:John Bauer - Princess Tuvstarr gazing down into the dark waters of the forest tarn. - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|300px|''Ännu sitter Tuvstarr kvar och ser ner i vattnet'' ("Still, Tuvstarr sits and gazes down into the water"), one of the most noted pictures by [[John Bauer (illustrator)|John Bauer]] from ''Among Gnomes and Trolls'', 1913]] {{for|the 1986 Sveriges Radio's Christmas calendar|Bland tomtar och troll (radio programme)}} '''''Among Gnomes and Trolls''''' ({{Lang-sv|Bland [[tomte|tomtar]] och [[troll]]}}), is a popular [[Sweden|Swedish]] folklore and fairy tales annual and children's fairy tale anthology published since 1907. One of the most noted of the early illustrators is artist [[John Bauer (illustrator)|John Bauer]].
== Writers and illustrators == [[File:Nej, sicken liten puttefnasker! Ropade trollet.jpg|thumb|200px|"Oh my, What a little runt! exclaimed the Troll."- ''The boy who was never afraid'', 1912]] Founded in 1907,<ref name=Museum>{{cite web|title=Bland tomtar och troll |url=http://www.jkpglm.se/Samlingarna/Konst/Om-John-Bauer-pa-Jonkopings-lans-museum/Sagokonstnaren/Bland-tomtar-och-troll/ |website=www.jkpglm.se |publisher=Jönköpings läns museum |accessdate=June 18, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123031625/http://www.jkpglm.se/Samlingarna/Konst/Om-John-Bauer-pa-Jonkopings-lans-museum/Sagokonstnaren/Bland-tomtar-och-troll/ |archivedate=November 23, 2015 }}</ref> and continuing to this very day,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://libris.kb.se/bib/8261516?vw=full&tab1=vers|title=Bland tomtar och troll|publisher=[[LIBRIS]]}}</ref> several of the foremost Swedish authors and illustrators have worked for the annual.
The first four volumes were illustrated by [[John Bauer (illustrator)|John Bauer]]. Volume 5 (1911) was illustrated by Norwegian illustrator Louis Moe, after which Bauer resumed illustrating from 1912 to 1915 (volumes 6-9). 1916 had no issue, but the series continues in 1917, illustrated by Aina Masolle and Gustaf Tengren, marking the series' first woman illustrator. From 1918 to 1926 Gustaf Tenggren was the sole illustrator. Between 1927 and 1980, [[Einar Norelius]] was the chief illustrator. Among the writers were authors such as [[Hjalmar Bergman]], [[Helena Nyblom]], [[Margareta Ekström]], [[Gösta Knutsson]] and [[Edith Unnerstad]].<ref name=Museum />
Several books with extracts from the original volumes illustrated by John Bauer have been published. The first one was published in 1931 to raise money for a memorial honouring Bauer.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bauer|first=John|title=John Bauers bästa: ett urval sagor ur Bland tomtar och troll åren 1907–1915|date=1931|publisher=Åhlén & Åkerlund|location=Stockholm|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/john-bauers-basta-ett-urval-sagor-ur-bland-tomtar-och-troll-aren-1907-1915/oclc/492479986|accessdate=February 2, 2015}}</ref>
One of the most noted pictures from "Among gnomes and trolls" by John Bauer 1913 is ''Ännu sitter Tuvstarr kvar och ser ner i vattnet'' ("Still, Tuvstarr sits and gazes down into the water").<ref>{{cite book|last=Agrenius|first=Helen|date=1996|title=Om konstnären John Bauer och hans värld|url=http://libris.kb.se/bib/7751744|language=Swedish|location=Jönköping|publisher=Jönköpings läns museum|page=45|isbn=91-85692-29-8|accessdate=July 20, 2014}}</ref>
== List of tales == Complete list of the tales in the series, 1907–1910 and 1912–1915, illustrated by John Bauer as well as the tales in the 1911 volume illustrated by Louis Moe.<ref name=Museum /><ref>{{cite book|editor=Olenius Elsa|title=John Bauers sagovärld: en vandring bland tomtar och troll, riddare och prinsessor tillsammans med några av våra främsta sagodiktare|date=1966|publisher=Bonnier|location=Stockholm|isbn=91-0-030396-8|url=http://libris.kb.se/bib/829457|accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Bauer|first1=John|last2=Bjurström|first2=Per|title=John Bauer: en konstnär och hans sagovärld|date=1982|publisher=Bra Böcker i samarbete med Nationalmus.|location=Höganäs|isbn=91-38-90217-6|url=http://libris.kb.se/bib/340329|accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref>
=== 1907 === *''En inledningsdikt'', Daniel Fallström
*''Sagan om Dag och Daga och flygtrollet på Skyberget'', Harald Östenson
*''Den förtrollade skogen'', Anna Wahlenberg
*''Lyckoblomman på Solberga klint'', Alfred Smedberg
*''Njunje Paggas äventyr'', P.A. Lindholm
*''Tomtens julafton'', Gurli Hertzman-Ericson
*''Pojken som spände trollet för kälken'', Harald Östenson
*''Han som kunde rida i alla väder'', Helena Nyblom
=== 1908 ===
[[File:Svanhamnen i Bland tomtar och troll, 1908..jpg|thumb|200px|"She wandered alone for hours."–''The Swan maiden'', John Bauer 1908.]] *''Svanhamnen'' '''("The Swan maiden")''', Helena Nyblom
*''Skinnpåsen'', Anna Wahlenberg
*''Konungens bägare'', Sophie Linge
*''Sagan om fiskaren Sikur och trollnätet'', Cyrus Granér
*''Den mäktige i det krossande berget'', Harald Östenson
=== 1909 ===
[[File:Men hur kommer man in i berget, frågade tomtepojken.jpg|thumb|200px|"Tjovik crept up onto the old troll's lap and stroked his beard."–''The trolls and the gnome boy'', John Bauer 1909.]] [[File:Vill Vallareman (a Fairy Shepherd) (John Bauer) - Nationalmuseum - 24283.tif|thumb|200px|Vill Vallareman (a Fairy Shepherd).]] *''Herr Birre och trollen'', Vilhälm Nordin
*''Sagan om de fyra stortrollen och lille Vill-Vallareman'', Cyrus Granér
*''Trollen och tomtepojken'' '''("The trolls and the gnome boy")''', Alfred Smedberg
*''Tomtarna'', Anna Wahlenberg
*''Skogsväktarne'', Jeanna Oterdahl
=== 1910 ===
*''Agneta och sjökungen'', Helena Nyblom
*''Prinsen utan skugga'', Jeanna Oterdahl
*''Svartjätten och den heliga ljusastaken'', Ester Edquist
*''Pojken som gick till vindarnas håla'', Alfred Smedberg
*''Trollritten'', av Anna Wahlenberg
*''Pojken och tomtemössan'', Vilhälm Nordin
=== 1911 === *''Den Fiffige tomten vid Alleberg'', av Alfred Smedberg
*''Trasnidaren'', av Jeanna Otterdahl
*'' Brummel-Bas i Berget'', av Gurli Hertzman-Ericson
*''Molnbrollopet'', av Vilhalm Nordin
*''Skönheten och odjuret'', av Helena Nyblom
=== 1912 ===
[[File:Här ska du få en bit av en trollört, som ingen mer än jag kan leta rätt på.jpg|thumb|200px|"Here is a piece of magic herb for you. Something only I can find."–''The boy who was never afraid'', John Bauer 1912.]] *''Oskuldens vandring'', Helena Nyblom
*''Trollkarlens kappa'', Anna Wahlenberg
*''Trollsonen som hade solögon och vart skogsman'', Vilhälm Nordin
*''Vingas krans'', Ellen Lundberg-Nyblom
*''Pojken som aldrig var rädd'' '''("The boy who was never afraid"'''), Alfred Smedberg
=== 1913 ===
[[File:The Princess and the Trolls (John Bauer) - Nationalmuseum - 24305.tif|thumb|200px|"One evening around midsummer, they went with Bianca Maria deep into the forest."–''The Changeling'', John Bauer 1913.]] *''Broder Martin'', Emil Eliason
*''Bortbytingarna'' '''("The Changeling")''', Helena Nyblom
*''Sagan om äldtjuren Skutt och lilla prinsessan Tuvstarr'', Helge Kjellin
*''Kvastarnas kvast, alla kvastars kung'', Vilhälm Nordin
=== 1914 ===
[[File:Riddaren Rider (3) by John Bauer 1914.jpg|thumb|200px|"Once upon a time a prince was out riding in the moonlight."–''The ring'', John Bauer 1914.]] *''Ringen'' '''("The ring")''', Helena Nyblom
*''När trollmor skötte kungens storbyk'' '''("When Mother Troll did the laundry for the king")''', Elsa Beskow, illustrated by John Bauer
*''Drottningens halsband'' '''("The queens necklace")''', Anna Wahlenberg
*''Fågel Fenix vingpenna'', Jeanna Oterdahl
=== 1915 ===
[[File:Nå, hur är det med aptiten fortsatte trollmor.jpg|thumb|200px|"Well, how is your appetite? mother Troll continued."–''The boy and the troll or The Adventure'', John Bauer 1915.]] *''En riddare red fram'', Jeanna Oterdahl
*''Pojken och trollen eller Äventyret'' '''("The boy and the trolls or The Adventure")''', Walter Stenström
*''Spelmannen som fick madonnans guldsko'', Emil Linders
*''Guldnycklarna'', W.E. Björk
== References == <references />
[[Category:1907 books]] [[Category:Illustration]] [[Category:Western art]] [[Category:Series of children's books]] [[Category:Collections of fairy tales]] [[Category:Annual magazines]] [[Category:Fantasy anthology series]] [[Category:Swedish fairy tales]] [[Category:Swedish literary magazines]] [[Category:1907 establishments in Sweden]] [[Category:Swedish folklore]] [[Category:Legendary creatures in popular culture]] [[Category:Trolls in popular culture]] [[Category:Youth in Sweden]] [[Category:20th century in Sweden]] [[Category:21st century in Sweden]] [[Category:Series of books]]
